executive_summary: Despite pandemic-era disruptions, the popularity of temperature-sensitive foods has kept demand for long-distance refrigerated trucking resilient. Sustained consumer spending on frozen foods, fruits, vegetables and meats insulated the industry from major trends and protected an essential lifeline during the COVID-19 pandemic. Still, refrigerated truckers' revenue slipped in 2020 as plummeting diesel prices pushed them to remove fuel surcharges. Meanwhile, the industry's landscape has become more fragmented as manageable barriers to entry have made room for a flood of new entrants.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Downstream Markets' Reliance on Refrigerated Trucking Brings Security, Even Through Global Pandemics
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Temperature-sensitive food products are massively popular with consumers for a variety of reasons. Frozen foods cater to consumers' desire for convenience, while health consciousness drives demand for fresh fruits and vegetables. Beef, poultry and seafood are widely regarded as essential to a balanced and protein-filled diet.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Fuel Prices Drive Major Swings in Truckers' Revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The price of fuel is one of the largest expenses for long-distance refrigerated truckers. Diesel prices are especially susceptible to significant fluctuations that have a pronounced effect on refrigerated truckers' profit. Truckers preserve profit by passing most input cost hikes downstream through fuel surcharges.

Long-distance refrigerated trucking has become more fragmented since 2019. Manageable barriers to entry are allowing nonemployers to become even more prevalent in the industry, resulting in intensifying competition.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The industry's freight is temperature-sensitive and must be kept at specific conditions at all times.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Successful truckers establish strong reputations by using diagnostic applications and devices to ensure trailers are constantly working.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: L A R G E  T R U C K I N G  F I R M S  A R E  O U T P E R F O R M I N G  S M A L L E R  C O M P E T I T O R S
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Large refrigerated trucking companies have more resources to invest in advanced technologies, like route and refueling optimization software. Protection from diesel price volatility helps the industry's top trucking services cope better with volatile diesel prices, allowing them to offer lower fuel surcharges that give them a competitive edge.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: R E L I A B L E  D E M A N D  W I L L  K E E P  R E V E N U E  T R E N D I N G  U P W A R D S
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Long-distance refrigerated truckers will remain protected from external competition as other industries simply can't match truck transportation's quality, speed and flexibility. Refrigerated rail and air transportation companies aren't one-to-one substitutes for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising consumer spending will support sales of temperature-sensitive products
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rising consumer spending will support sales of temperature-sensitive products, like frozen food, fruits, vegetables and meats. At the same time, growing disposable incomes will support demand for discretionary products transported by the industry, like cosmetics.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: FUEL COSTS WILL SINK AS PRODUCTION RECOVERS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The price of diesel and gas is set to dip from post-pandemic highs as domestic production swells and catches up to demand. Lower fuel expenses will force truckers to reduce or remove fuel surcharges, straining revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: TRUCKING COMPANIES WILL NEED TO INVEST IN GREENER TRUCKS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The EPA finalized a new rule in March 2024 to limit greenhouse gas emissions from heavy-duty vocational vehicles, including refrigerated trucks. These tightened regulations will apply to every truck model year 2027 through 2032. Trucking companies and truck manufacturers oppose these rules, calling them unrealistic. The oil industry's trade associations have vowed to challenge the EPA's new rule in court.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Profit Will Swell As Labor Becomes More Available
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Congress proposed the DRIVE Safe Integrity Act in 2023 to improve road safety and address the ongoing labor shortage. The Act allows the Department of Transportation to establish commercial driver's license (CDL) apprenticeship programs for adults under 21, expanding the potential base of employees for long-distance refrigerated truckers.

industry_definition: Industry operators provide long-distance refrigerated trucking services, moving climate-sensitive products ranging from meat and poultry to pharmaceuticals and cosmetics, among other goods. Goods are typically transported from manufacturers to wholesalers and retailers throughout the United States.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Refrigerated trucking has low barriers to entry. Anyone with a commercial driver's license (CDL), a truck and the proper equipment can begin competing in the industry. Over half the industry's long-distance refrigerated trucking enterprises are sole proprietors.

Large companies offer various services that many smaller truckers can't. Reputable refrigerated trucking companies can supplement revenue from truckload transportation with freight forwarding or consulting services.

Refrigerated truckers' freight insulates them from economic shocks across the economy. While the COVID-19 pandemic halted many operations, refrigerated truckers were still needed to transport frozen and perishable foods.

Fuel surcharges help truckers maintain profit levels amid volatile diesel prices. Fuel costs also drive massive swings in revenue: skyrocketing diesel prices in the wake of the pandemic brought massive revenue growth for truckers. The Russia-Ukraine war has kept fuel costs high since.

The industry receives little government assistance. Trade organizations somewhat make up for a lack of federal support by advocating for pro-industry legislation and providing research into the logistics sector.

Refrigeration truckers must abide by multiple government regulations to ensure the safety of their drivers and their surroundings. Rules range from the handling of hazardous materials to driving time limits.

Fuel is one of the top expenses for refrigerated truckers, and prices can be volatile. Trucking companies can usually pass these costs down to customers in the form of fuel surcharges to preserve some profit.

Refrigerated trucking remains labor-intensive. Driving time limits force companies to hire additional drivers or dramatically drop delivery times, and an ongoing labor shortage is making it difficult for trucking companies to replace retiring employees.
The abundance of manufacturers in the Great Plains makes it a popular destination for refrigerated truckers. It is also near many trading ports, allowing companies to carry imports and exports.

The Southeast's population translates to the largest percentage of refrigerated truckers. Its large consumer base creates high demand for retailers, which must be regularly supplied to ensure they can feed the quarter of the nation living in the region.

Wholesalers and retailers generate most of the industry's revenue. Most refrigerated truckers carry food for resale to consumers. Refrigerated trucking makes up the bulk of revenue, but companies may offer other services to diversify sales. Transporting nonperishable goods alongside frozen foods can help maximize each trip's returns.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The most popularly shipped temperature-sensitive goods are food items like meat, fish and dairy products. Clients buy these products for resale to consumers, so wholesalers and retailers generate more than half of the industry's revenue.

Food manufacturers also buy fresh or frozen food products for further processing. Manufacturers use dairy, meat and vegetable products to create ready-to-eat meals, boxed recipes and packaged foods. As consumers have grown more concerned about the nutritional value of processed food, many have switched to organic products. This shift has bolstered demand for transport direct-to-store at the cost of truckers servicing food manufacturers.

Long-distance refrigerated truckers rarely provide services to other markets. Still, extreme summer heat can promote the industry's popularity in niche markets as new clients hire refrigerated truckers to transport products like cosmetics or adhesives that don't hold up well under abnormally high temperatures. Well-reputed trucking companies can also offer freight consolidation, forwarding or consulting to other logistics companies. These services have become more popular amid supply chain issues, new technologies and pressure to streamline operations amid high fuel costs.

products_and_services.product_description: Refrigerated truckload transportation involves the long-distance transportation of temperature-sensitive goods. These services comprise over 75.0% of the industry's revenue.

This segment also includes intermodal shipments of refrigerated containers. Truckers carry climate-controlled loads for transfer to other shipping options, like rail or ship. Intermodal deliveries are far less popular as it's cheaper for long-distance truckers to deliver to end destinations on their own.

Many trucking companies provide brokerage services by arranging for other companies to transport freight while retaining the billing, collection and customer management responsibilities. Large trucking companies are overwhelmingly responsible for revenue generated through brokerage as they contract out some jobs to nonemployees. Long-distance refrigeration truckers also sometimes offer logistics consulting. Clients seek reputable truckers' help planning routes and coordinating delivery times for their most sensitive goods.

tier_1_suppliers: Truck & Bus Manufacturing in the US
Truck, Trailer & Motor Home Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Gasoline & Petroleum Wholesaling in the US
Auto Parts Stores in the US
tier_2_buyers: Egg & Poultry Wholesaling in the US
Freight Forwarding Brokerages & Agencies in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Frozen food products must be transported aboard refrigerated trucks to preserve freshness and ensure compliance with food safety regulations. When demand for frozen food products decreases, upstream production capacities contract and refrigerated truckers see smaller freight volumes. Conversely, growth in demand for frozen food presents a potential opportunity for long-distance refrigerated truckers.

Rising trade volumes lift the number of climate-sensitive products passing into or out of the US. Long-distance refrigeration truckers serve as middlemen, carrying products from the border to distribution hubs in the US's interior. Truckers also carry domestic goods to ports for transport to overseas markets. Accordingly, a rise in the nation's total trade value boosts revenue for long-distance refrigeration truckers.

Consumer spending levels increase when disposable income and consumer confidence levels are high. When consumer spending increases, producers of climate-sensitive goods up their capacities. Since heightened production upstream creates more freight for truckers to carry, long-distance refrigeration truckers generate revenue growth when consumer spending climbs.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand From Fruit and Vegetable Wholesaling
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Fruit and vegetable farmers, wholesalers and retailers rely on refrigerated trucks to keep produce fresh throughout the supply chain. When there is greater demand for fruits and vegetables that need to be shipped, the need for refrigerated trucking rises. Conversely, long-distance refrigerated truckers face a decline in demand when consumers purchase fewer fruits and vegetables.

Long-distance refrigerated trucking companies rely on diesel to operate their fleets. When the price of diesel surges, truckers impose fuel surcharges to protect profit. Still, competition often keeps truckers from fully passing heightened diesel costs downstream. While refrigerated truckers' revenue typically swells alongside rising diesel prices, heightened expenses cut into profit. Accordingly, diesel prices' regular volatility poses a potential threat to long-distance refrigerated truckers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Meat, Beef and Poultry Processing
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Meat, beef and poultry producers make up a significant market for long-distance refrigerated truckers, as these products are temperature-sensitive and spoil if not transported correctly. When consumers purchase more meat, beef and poultry, farmers increase their headcounts and outputs. As meat processing ramps up, so does the need for refrigerated transportation.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast hosts almost one-quarter of the nation's refrigerated trucking companies. The Southeast holds the highest percentage of the US population, driving robust downstream demand for truckers. Located along the Mississippi River, the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean, the Southeast region benefits from massive influxes of people and traded goods.
Texas has more long-distance refrigerated truckers than any other state. The growing population in Austin and other major Texas cities has led to an uptick in industries.

The Great Lakes is the manufacturing capital of the United States, with major industries operating out of the region. The region has access to multiple transportation networks to connect different industries. Chicago is a land transportation hub for Asian imports and hosts a plethora of refrigerated truckers to help deliver these goods to their destination.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FMCSA limits how long drivers can operate. Truckers often use two drivers per trip to comply.
The FMCSA requires refrigerated truckers to install ELDs to monitor driving time and ensure compliance with regulations.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Hazardous Material Transportation Act of 1975
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Act permits oversight on safe packaging of hazardous materials like pharmaceuticals transported by refrigerated truckers.
Truckers must register and pay fees based on fleet size annually to this federal program that enforces safety.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Truckers must have a commercial driver's license to be eligible for employment. Truckers must also follow regulations regarding hazardous materials, driving time and carbon emissions.
Refrigerated trucks must rent or purchase a refrigerator trailer and have a proper logistics and communication system to connect with drivers and trucks.
Truckers can differentiate themselves through price, capacity and timeliness. Reputation is key to major clients, so trucking companies need to establish a proven track record for quality.
While there are capital investments, the backbone of refrigerated trucking hinges on its employees. Hiring and retaining qualified drivers is essential.

basis_points.basis_description: Refrigerated trucking has low barriers to entry. Anyone with a commercial driver's license (CDL), a truck and the proper equipment can begin competing in the industry. Over half the industry's long-distance refrigerated trucking enterprises are sole proprietors.

Large companies offer various services that many smaller truckers can't. Reputable refrigerated trucking companies can supplement revenue from truckload transportation with freight forwarding or consulting services.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Nonemployers are extremely common. The industry is highly fragmented. The four biggest trucking firms make up less than 20.0% of the market, so concentration is low.

More than half of all long-distance refrigeration truckers are owner-operators. These independent truckers leverage manageable barriers to entry to begin competing as sole proprietors with no employees.

Large truckers maintain their market share by entering long-term contracts with large manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers. Clients aren't likely to switch to a smaller competitor without a proven track record for protecting temperature-sensitive products.

Major trucking companies hold several advantages over nonemployers. Their reputations and economies of scale help them boast larger client bases, and their ability to overcome driving time limit laws by hiring multiple drivers helps them speed up delivery times.

Many owner-operators work under arrangements with larger trucking companies. This collaboration gives nonemployers access to larger client pools but can bring volatility as major players expand or contract their operating capacities.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Diesel is the top purchasing expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Diesel is by far the industry's top purchasing expense. Electric or hydrogen trucks are still scarce in the industry, so most refrigerated truckers are heavily exposed to changes in crude oil prices.
As trucks become too outdated or expensive to repair, local freight truckers buy new ones.
Refrigerated truckers also need to regularly buy spare parts for their trucks and trailers. Wheels and brake pads are trucks' most commonly replaced items.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While there are capital investments, the backbone of refrigerated trucking hinges on its employees. Hiring and retaining qualified drivers is essential to success.
Refrigerated truckers need to regularly purchase new trucks, trailers, and spare parts which require significant capital investments.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Rising diesel prices force long-distance refrigerated truckers to implement fuel surcharges to account for additional expenses and protect profit. Revenue surges when truckers hike rates.

volatility_points.volatility_title: International trade plays a smaller role in revenue fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: Goods imported or exported within North America are often transported by long-distance refrigerated truckers. However, factors like exchange rates and events like the pandemic can impact trade volumes.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Upstream innovations help truckers protect freight
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: New product launches by upstream manufacturers focus on improving refrigerated transport quality while reducing operating costs for trucking companies.
Predictive analytics and fuel-routing software help optimize routes, fuel stops, and driver availability to increase efficiency.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Autonomous trucking slowly becoming a reality
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies like Gatik have established short autonomous truck routes. While long-distance is difficult currently, innovations may eventually restructure the industry.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The Long-Distance Refrigerated Trucking industry is a key component of the US economy as a whole. When consumer spending and industrial production are high, as well as trade, revenue will be substantial.

FAQs.question: How does your company compete for long-term contracts?
FAQs.answer: A majority companies and owner-operators will work with freight brokers or directly with companies. A strong reputation is critical to obtaining long-term contracts.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising diesel costs over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Diesel is a key expenditure for operators. Companies will either secure future contracts or use surcharges to hedge against changes in the price of fuel moving upwards.

FAQs.question: Is your operation located in an area with many potential customers?
FAQs.answer: Demand is primarily generated by food manufacturing and retailers/wholesalers. Access to key markets is crucial for consistent workloads.

FAQs.question: How have ELDs affected your company?
FAQs.answer: ELDs limit how many hours a driver can run, automatically logging engine running time and other records. They will improve fuel efficiency and other operational efficiencies and ensure better driver safety. It may also create operating inefficiencies and delivery delays.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations?
FAQs.answer: Wages typically account for more than 20.0% of revenue on average. While high driver revenue is necessary, automation can improve other aspects of operation and reduce payroll.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Profit is heavily determined by the price of fuel. However, spending on upgrades to improve fuel efficiency and meet EPA standards, as well as other operational elements affected by regulation, can have a substantial impact.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: The EPA has implemented vital fuel efficiency requirements to reduce emissions. Newer trucks must meet minimum requirements, which has altered industry incentives.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Small efficiency improvements and effective diesel purchasing can make a big difference. These margins are more significant than a number of different freight trucking industries, such as general freight.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Many companies will forego the option of purchasing new equipment. Trucks and trailers are typically costly, meaning operators choose to lease/broker loads to owner-operators.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? What qualifications must your staff have?
FAQs.answer: The industry competes intensely for skilled drivers, so attracting and retaining employees is critical for success in the industry.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Have you had any problems with reliability in the past?
FAQs.answer: Having an established reputation for delivering products on time and in good condition is crucial for success. Long-distance refrigerated trucking often transports time-sensitive products that will spoil if not delivered on time and under the right temperature.

FAQs.question: Can you access the latest and most efficient technology and techniques? How do you achieve and maintain good product quality?
FAQs.answer: High-quality equipment, including newer fleets and cutting-edge communication technology, enables operators to minimize repair and maintenance costs, improve productivity and boost profitability.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue depends on demand from meat, beef and poultry? Are there other revenue streams you can pursue to increase demand?
FAQs.answer: Meat, beef and poultry make up a significant market for the industry as the products are temperature-sensitive and spoil if not transported correctly.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the price of diesel? How will increasing diesel prices impact your company?
FAQs.answer: The trucks in this industry primarily use diesel fuel in their operations.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of trade activity? Are you prepared to meet changing demand as trade activity changes?
FAQs.answer: The industry receives a significant amount of revenue from the transportation of climate-sensitive goods that have been imported into the United States or are in the process of being exported.
